nodes.text: The paper examines how political institutions, measured by incumbency consent requirements, determine dynamic selection and persistence of governments and their flexibility to adapt to environmental shocks

Method: a simple dynamic discrete-time game where feasible governments are coalitions, each government has a competence value that determines collective utility, individuals obtain rents from office, and government changes require both citizen votes and consent of some current members

Assumption: individuals' stage payoffs increase in government competence and each individual strictly prefers any government that includes her to any government that excludes her; competence functions are distinct across feasible governments
Assumption (specialization): government competence can be represented as an increasing function of members' abilities, typically the sum of individual abilities
Result (nonstochastic): perfect democracy (no incumbency consent required) always leads to emergence of the most competent government

Result (nonstochastic): any deviation from perfect democracy (positive incumbency consent l>0) guarantees existence of at least one other stable government; even the least competent government can be stable and persist forever in equilibrium

Claim: there is no general ranking among imperfect democracies and dictatorships in nonstochastic environments; some less democratic regimes can yield better long-run governments depending on initial membership and parameter values

Method / equilibrium concept: define Markov political equilibrium via a transition mapping on feasible governments; characterize existence and uniqueness of an acyclic political equilibrium for high discount factor and infrequent shocks (Theorems 1-3)

Mechanism / explanation: incumbency consent creates strategic resistance by current members who fear chained future transitions that would exclude them, so they block reforms even if reforms would increase societal competence
Model evidence: formal results and examples illustrate how small incumbency advantages (even one consenting member) can make worst governments stable and prevent inclusion of high-ability technocrats

Result (stochastic): with rare stochastic shocks to competences, greater democracy (lower incumbency consent l) increases flexibility and raises the probability the most competent government will come to power over time

Mechanism (stochastic): more democratic regimes have fewer nearby stable governments around a given state, so shocks that destabilize the current government are more likely to result in transitions to higher competence governments over time

Conclusion and implications: incumbency protections produce inertia that can lock in low competence governments, while reducing incumbency consent promotes adaptability; institutions shape long run political selection and policy outcomes
